ygData.subject: Re: A question about the Double Pole Benchmark experiment.
ygData.msgSnippet: No, we don t really know that.  The physics model has been carried forward for several generations of systems, so it is a kind of uniform benchmark

No, we don't really know that.  The physics model has been carried forwar=
d for several generations of systems, so it is a kind of uniform benchmark =
environment, but to my knowledge it is not validated whether or not it corr=
esponds to the real world.  However, the pole balancers evolved by various =
systems in this environment have been analyzed extensively, so we at least =
we know that the solutions are doing what we think they are doing (e.g. dam=
ping oscillations), which suggests that the physics model is good enough to=
 provide the kind of problem it attempts to provide.

ken

--- In neat@yaho=
ogroups.com, Colin Green <colin.green1@...> wrote:
>

> > In fact, there is a solution to the=
 no-velocity version that has only a single hidden neuron. In
> > fact, the=
re is a solution with no hidden neurons (which must have a recurrent connec=
tion on
> > the output). The pole balancing tasks turned out to require muc=
h less structure than was
> > thought, which is something NEAT discovered.
=
> 
> Do we know if this is an artifact of the physics model?
> 
> Colin.
>
